title: YAFR - Yet Another Filament Reel (Parametric)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
USE customizer to create custom sized reels - run twice changing thread type to create both male and female parts.

SCAD file allows user to change flange diameter and thickness, and hub inner diameter and width. Side openings are provided for filament catch and air flow during dehydration. Sides thread together to allow use of small rolls like the $5.00 samples from ProtoParadigm, and change samples easily without having to wind and unwind.

Sample files are Flange 200mm hub 55 mm by 60mm wide to match Hatchbox reels and 120mm flange with 60mm hub 30mm wide for small remnants or samples.

description.text:
A newer version with a screw-on lamp chassis can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2078413

I played around with the parameters of my old design http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1216198 a bit and actually got it printable. I had to reduce image resolution and contrast and added a border to get rid of the parts that always get too small. The sphere is also not flattened anymore, instead the top is cut off to have a flat surface and rotated to lie on the print bed. I printed the dog in 0.1mm resolution and Mona Lisa even in 0.3mm, this is working fine without the need for support.
The customizer takes pictures with 55x55 pixels. The preview is a little buggy, but the rendered files are fine. Higher resolution requires a bigger radius, this scales about linear, so to have twice the resolution twice the radius is required so details will not get too small. For this you can download the scad file locally and create the image array with this script: http://jsfiddle.net/threonin/6dr8qu41/
I used Simplify3D for slicing, Slic3r also seems to be able to handle it.

A high res version with 85x85 pixels is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1923764

comments.text: These projectors are great! Well done! But I am curious... why do you call them "stereographic" projectors? I mean, there is some sterographic effect that doesn't show in the pictures?
comments.author: mdiez

comments.text: Thanks! It is the name of the operation used to map a plane to a sphere that is used to create the projectors: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stereographic_projection
comments.author: mdiez

comments.text: Thanks. I got confused because nowadays the term stereography is being used in reference to the projection of a pair of images representing the same scene from each eyes' POV to reconstruct the stereo 3D image.

description.text:
Same as my other split tree sculpture, it starts as an extruded equilateral triangle, splits into four pieces which fork upward at an angle to form four new triangles. These continue to split until there are 256 triangles at the very top. I usually display it upside-down after printing, but have never tried printing it this way because it would be difficult to properly remove from the print bed.

Bonus fact: This sculpture has the exact same cross sectional area from the bottom to the top due to the effect of the splitting.

Printer:

Flashforge Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.3 mm

Infill:

20%-100%

Notes:

I use Simplify3D settings to give each split a different infill. For the base I do 20%, then going up I do 30%, 50%, 100%, and 100%.

You don't have to do this, but without it, you'll either end up with a rather long print or hollow tips on the end.

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

The square hole on the second piece is smaller than the square end on the axle so that each piece can filed down for a tight friction fit. (This has worked well for a few weeks of daily walks, but if it proves to wear and loosen it will be redesigned to include a detent so it will “click” in place.)

We printed this in Makerbot "True White" PLA.
I used Autodesk 123DDesign to create this print model.

The canvas bags that attach to a walking leash with a hook-and-loop strap are lightweight, strong and very convenient. However when pulling out a bag through the slot in the side of the carrier, sometimes the roll jams against the inside of the bag. This spindle insert is keeps the roll from jamming.

The spindle is printed in two parts. After the roll is inserted on the part with the axle, the second piece is placed onto the open end.

The spindle is sized to fit tightly in the canvas carrier. Once the roll is installed on the spindle, we’ve found that the easiest way to install the spindle is to place one end inside the carrier and then press on the other side of the spindle to stretch the carrier so that the other side of the spindle slips into place.

author: tatestubbs

title: Robo 3D Hall-O magnet holder for Z end stop

description.text: This is a simple magnet holder for the Z axis end stop.  You will need to tap the threads of the portion that fits the bolt.

Do you hate constantly readjusting the end stop?  Have you basically stripped out the screw because none of your screwdrivers quite fit the screw provided?  Do you feel like you're going to break the vertical support post every time you try to adjust the home height?  
If so, this mod is for you.  This is the first mod I did and it is a lifesaver.  I don't have to tweak the home position every single print and, when I do, it's pretty simple because I just adjust the pot on the sensor until I get the right height using a feeler gauge.

Buy Stuff
--
The first thing you'll need is a hall effect sensor. I used the Hall-O from here. Buy the 9 euro version unless you want to do your own surface mount soldering:
http://mauk.cc/store.html As an alternative, this should work as well:
http://www.reprapdiscount.com/electronics/18-set-hall-endstops3-pieces.html

Wire it up
--
Next, you'll need a connector and some wires. The switch on the Robo is two wire and they only provided a two wire connector. Fortunately, these are cheap from Pololu. You'll want a pack of these:
http://www.pololu.com/product/1803 and a pack of these:
http://www.pololu.com/product/1902 Solder these to the end stop and then proceed to the next step. Red wire to 5V
Black wire to Ground
Yellow Wire toe Signal Slot them into the 1x3 connector as Red, Black, Yellow and then plug it into the RAMPS board. The red should line up with the + symbol

Mount the sensor
--
The hole width for the switch holder is not the same as my hall effect sensor. I will eventually design something for this but, for now, I just used one screw with a nut below and above the sensor. See the picture. You'll need some way to mount the magnet. I started by taping the magnet to the end of the bolt but quickly created the attached file for holding the magnet. You'll need to tap the threads for the bolt portion to match the end stop trigger bolt. You'll probably need to back the endstop screw quite a ways back for this to work. Before you insert the magnet, go read up on this sensor and notice that you need to bend the tip 90 degrees and the magnet only works one way. If you insert it into the magnet holder backwards, it will not work.

Program the controller
--
You'll need to make the following change to Configuration.h. On the version, I'm using, this starts at line 256. // The pullups are needed if you directly connect a mechanical endswitch between the signal and ground pins.
const bool X_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.
const bool Y_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.
const bool Z_MIN_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = true; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.
const bool X_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.
const bool Y_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop.
const bool Z_MAX_ENDSTOP_INVERTING = false; // set to true to invert the logic of the endstop. Note the "true" on the Z Min endstop?

title: Customizable Helix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This customizable helix was originally designed as a bridging torture test. After finding that most of helix I found had defects in the models, points that didn't connect, I set off to make my own. I hope you guys enjoy. The full commented code can be found at (https://midheaventech.tumblr.com/post/153785237750/3ddesignpost1), and I strongly suggest taking a look at it to better understand it's settings. There I've listed two codes that produce the same helix. The two codes demonstrate a simplified and complex way to create the same model, and some would say a right and wrong way.
The settings on the customizer are extreme and you really only need to change them by small values, however I put exaggerated values because it can be fun to play with, and I want to see what others create. :)

2017 NEW YEAR

This is my first attempt on making a Nerf foam dart gun. "Version 1"
The idea is to create a Nerf gun the can be printed on almost all printers.
The reason for this is. I own a HobbyKing Turnigy Fabrikator Mini aka TinyBoy. with a print volume of only 80x80x80mm.
This makes it challenging when designing big parts that I would like to print.

DON'T PRINT
This gun will unfortunately not shoot the dart at a speed that would be fun.
The small parts to hold the 2 barrels together tend to break off when firing the gun.
So only print it if you like the design and wants to use it as a prop gun for some cosplay or something.

Shopping list:
126mm tube (electrical) ø16mm / 5/8" (OD 16mm, ID 13,5mm)
ø13x2mm O-Ring or around that size.
1pcs. Spring OD 15mm, ID 12mm, L 51mm.
1pcs. Spring from a ballpen. Cut in half. Both halves are used.
2pcs. 3x12mm socket screws.
2pcs. 3x6mm countersunk screws.
7pcs. 3x12mm countersunk screws.
1pcs. 4x10mm countersunk screw.

Printer:

Fabrikator Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 / 0.2

Infill:

25% / 100%

Notes:

Printed in PLA.
I printed the Trigger, Trigger protection, Piston, Piston shaft and Lock at 0.1 layer and with 100% infill.
The other parts I printed at 0.2 layer and 25% infill
Total print time 25 hours 26 minutes
Designed using Solidworks

description.text: This helicopter would be the perfect transportation to get presents delivered to boys and girls around the world.  It would also make a great gift and ornament.  Have fun building it first, then hang it on the tree, or display with other decorations.  I have printed all the pieces and tried it out.  It takes time, but it all fits together, and the finished product gives great joy.  Print it all together, or in separate pieces.  It is up to your level of challenge.  Pictures show modeled scene and actual printed design using my Makerbot Rep 2.  I now have 2x and can't wait to print one with support material.

I started with basic building blocks that I measured and drew in CAD.  The designs were taken into 3D Studio Max to be extruded, booleaned, and edges softened with fillets.  The files were assembled and exported as STL files.

Tom Swift's space kite. this is the prototype 2 person dome shaped version.

How does the Space Kite work? The space kite uses cosmic radiation as a power source. It uses a rocket to launch itself above the atmosphere to where the cosmic radiation is intense enough to provide thrust.

The design of the space kite was beautifully simple. The pilot and copilot, with their control board, would be enclosed in the front part by a plain transparent plastic dome. Behind their seats, the dome was partitioned off by the flat "screen layers" of Tom's cosmic reactor—the device for converting cosmic radiation into motive power. From the center of the reactor, a cone protruded out behind like a stubby comet's tail. This was to be the directional-aiming cone of the gravitex.

3 versions here. One with steps and rails, one with steps and no rails and another without rails or steps. These were printed with .2 mm layer height on a replicator 1 with no support.   
Added a version that includes rails on the floor, crows nest, and crown.. Makes it look a little better.  
Updated the zip file to include all the stl files and the .scad and .dxf files that I used to draw it.

Be sure the model sticks to the build platform. I used acetone and abs on the build plate (works wonderfully even when printing PLA).
.2mm layers looks good. The 50% model takes about 30 mins to print... The 75% model takes about 80 minutes. Just for clarity, the stl files are already scaled to 50,75, and 98%

print_settings.Notes:: The thickness is 3mm, and I wanted it to be completely made of edges, so I set my slicer to have a 1.6mm outer wall thickness (cura wants wall thickness in multiples of the nozzle size).

description.text:
Not terribly decorative, but it does the trick of holding a stocking over the mantle without damaging the wood. It's not critical that it "pinches" the wood, it really works just by making sure the loop of the stocking is held underneath the mantle.

The gap distance is about 26mm, so if you want it to pinch, just scale the entire thing with your slicer.

To make it more decorative, someone should use red/green filament, and change it a few times in the print (maybe like green on the outside, and red on the inside? That would look good, I think).

Notes:

The thickness is 3mm, and I wanted it to be completely made of edges, so I set my slicer to have a 1.6mm outer wall thickness (cura wants wall thickness in multiples of the nozzle size).

description.text:
A parent came to me asking if I could make a 3D printed case for her diabetic son that uses Nightscout and Motorola Moto G4 phone with the Dexcon G4 receiver. The two devices talk to each other through a usb cable and monitors blood glucose levels. I found this one on Thingiverse:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:771324
However, this model was the wrong size for the Moto G4 phone - so I adjusted it to fit and after a couple of iterations, I got the sizing right.
Moto G4 Phone dimensions:
Phone dimensions: 53 x 76.6 x 9.8 mm (6.02 x 3.02 x 0.39 in)

A bubble light ornament is a liquid-filled vial that is heated and lighted by an incandescent light bulb. Because of the liquid's low boiling point, the modest heat generated by the lamp causes the liquid to boil and bubble up from the vial's base thus creating the bubble light. The liquid is almost always methylene chloride, but some early bubble lights used a lightweight oil. The light from the lamp illuminates the bubbles from underneath, causing them to shine. As Christmas lights, bubble lights were very popular during the 1950s through the 1970s

author: gustofusion

description.text:
This is a hinge cap for a Toshiba R50B or R50C - I've used it on both of those. I imagine it'll fit other related models too. It doesn't clip in exactly, and this is intentional: This was designed for use at a school, where students keep stealing the hinge caps, so replacing them with another easily-removed cap wouldn't last. Instead this is designed to be fastened into place by running the tip of a soldering iron along the seam to melt the plastic together, or using a solvent cement, and removed in a simlar manner should it ever be necessary. For this reason it must be made of ABS, not PLA.

This is a left hinge. If you want a right hinge, just mirror it. Sorry, but no kensington hole. I also strongly suggest you give it a vapor smooth, in order to fuse the layers and give it a bit more strength.

title: Storage box (explorers & pirates)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the storage-solution for my explorers & pirates expansion: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1588996

To use this box you need to have printed the main game and the seafarers expansion allready. The box offers space for the following hex-pieces:
19 x water
1 x council
1 x wool
1 x wood
4 x gold
6 x spice
6 x fish
1 x ore
1 x counter-fish-victory-point
1 x counter-spice-victory-point
1 x counter-gold-victory-point

For the box you need to print the following parts:
2 x storage core (If you used self-adhesive-foil to cover the buttom of your tiles or anything that makes them thicker than the original files, print 2 x storage core big)
1 x storage part 2
1 x storage top
1 x storage center (If you used self-adhesive-foil to cover the buttom of your tiles or anything that makes them thicker than the original files, print storage center big)
1 x storage center top
1 x council (placeholder)
6 x spice (placeholder)
6 x fish (placeholder)

All the other placeholder-parts you find them here:

  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1482713
  • http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1839595

The biggest sices you need to print are 19.5 cm x 20.00 cm (7.67 x 7,87 inches). So make shure you're printerbed is big enough. For transporting the box, make sure that you grab it on the bottom, not the top...

Have fun :-)

title: Tablet stand (2 positions) with bubbles
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Remix from the Versatile multi-angle phone/tablet stand. (Remix from scratch)

Introduced DFM (Design for manufacturing), as the bridges over the high towers are hard to print (model has to be layed to be printed).
This remix is also more rigid than the original.

This stand is well suited for 7" Tablet (Amazon Fire 7 in my case) but should suit every other diagonal.

Multiple positions are convenient if you want to read something from the top (recepies, news) or when you want to watch something in front of you.

This model is also very stable!

I also add a opening for a future wall stand.

title: MouseMotel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE 2010-03-19
I\'ve added new pictures and completed the build and usage instructions. I spent my time on those so am still cleaning up the OpenSCAD files. UPDATE 2010-03-05
I\'ve uploaded two new STL files. These supersede all previous versions:
  • MouseMotel_0.3.stl
  • MouseMotelLid_0.3.stl
    • These are for a 70 mm ID bottle. I used a 20 oz/591 mL one.
    I\'ve uploaded an OpenSCAD screen grab of the parts assembled to show how they go together. Once I clean up the MouseMotel.scad file I will upload it too. UPDATE 2010-03-04
    I\'ve uploaded an STL file of the main part. I still need to tweak the flap that contains the mouse. UPDATE 2010-03-02
    Look at the photo; mine works!
    And it\'s still alive! ;) Seriously, since any garbage can contains a suitable enclosure for the trap, i.e., a soda or water bottle, I decide to focus on creating a printable one-way flap that can be fitted to a cut-down bottle. This reduces the size and number of parts necessary for the trap and because I used my favorite modeling tool, OpenSCAD, I parameterized the design so it can be used for bottles of various diameters. Here\'s the basic concept:
  • Cut off the top of your selected bottle
  • Size and print a ring that fits inside bottle
  • Print flap that sits inside the ring
  • Insert 2 3 mm captive nuts into holes on outside of ring
  • Insert ring into bottle
  • Punch/cut holes for stabilizers
  • Insert stabilizers into captive nuts
  • Insert a length of 3 mm plastic feedstock to function as the flap hinge pin
  • Place motel at desired location
  • Bait motel with peanut butter
  • Wait
    • The mouse will smell the bait, enter the one-way flap in the bottle to get it, and be trapped! The stabilizers on either side of the bottle will keep it from rolling around as the mouse explores its new home. I\'m still working on a few details, and will update this thing as I finalize them.

Tools
  • Scissors
  • Utility knife
  • M3 nut-driver
  • Vise or locking pliers
  • Drill bits
    • Materials Prep

  • Obtain a plastic soda bottle that is sized for your prey. I used a 20 oz/591 mL Sprite bottle with a 70 mm inside diameter (ID), for a theoretical mouse girth of 30 mm.

  • Squarely cut off the bottle top; do this right above the label top using scissors or a utility knife. You want to maintain as much of the flat bottle walls as possible, and following the label top makes it easy to cut the edge square.

  • Cut and thread two 100 mm lengths of ABS feedstock for use as stabilizers. If you'd rather use M3 bolts, you can skip this; I didn't have the correct length bolts, so I used feedstock instead. See below for feedstock threading instructions.

  • Cut one length of feedstock for use as the flap hinge pin. It should be about 20 mm longer than the ID of the bottle.
    You want all feedstock as straight as possible, so if necessary, slightly bend it to remove any coiling curves.
    • Printing

  • Skeinforge both MouseMotelLid_0.3.stl and MouseMotel_0.3.stl. I used an infill of 0.5.

  • Print MouseMotelFlap_0.3.stl.

  • Print MouseMotel_0.3.stl; it needs to be warp-free, so a heated build platform is recommended.
    • Assembly

  • Clean up the holes in both prints with a drill bit and trim the flap and entry tube with a utility knife as needed. A few threads of plastic in the entry tube are OK, but this is the entrance to the motel and you want it to be as inviting as possible for your guest. The M3 nuts and hinge pin should fit snugly in the ring, but the hinge pin should fit loosely in the flap hinge. The flap hinge should fit loosely in the front cutout, and when closed it must lay flush on the top of the entry tube. This last fitting is important because if it doesn't lay flat the mouse could lift the flap and check out early.

  • Place flat side of MouseMotel on horizontal surface and lower bottle over it.

  • Mark the bottle for the four holes: one for each side of the flap hinge pin, and two for the stabilizers.

  • Remove the ring and drill or punch the holes in the bottle at the marked locations. The holes should be slightly larger than the feedstock diameter.

  • Insert the flap hinge pin into one hole of the ring and guide it through a pillow block, into the flap hinge, through another pillow block, and finally into the opposite ring hole. The hinge pin should be flush with the outside of the opposite ring hole, such that one side protrudes out of the ring and the other doesn't.

  • Press M3 nuts into ring. If they are loose, use a drop of hot glue to secure them.

  • Place bait in bottle. I used a small dollop of creamy peanut butter.

  • With flat side of MouseMotel facing out, insert long side of feedstock hinge pin into correct hole in bottle. Tilt ring into bottle and align opposite ring and bottle holes. Push hinge pin into bottle hole. The ring should now be attached to the bottle with the hinge pin.

  • Rotate ring, and screw stabilizers entirely into captive M3 nuts. They will likely be long, so place MouseMotel on the edge of a table with the stabilizers facing downward. With the entry hole level, mark then cut stabilizers to the correct length. If bottle rocks, unscrew stabilizers as needed.

  • That's it! You are now a MouseMotelier!
    • Usage
    As in the human hospitality business, "location, location, location" is very important to attract a guest. Look for mouse droppings or chewed paper goods and place it nearby. As a good MouseMotelier, you should check the occupancy status at least once a day. Once you have a guest, place a piece of duct tape over the entry and take the MouseMotel to a release location. Once there, remove the duct tape and place the MouseMotel on the ground upside down. This will cause the flap to fall open and permit your guest to check out. Threading 3 mm ABS Feedstock FTW!
    This is a little tricky, but if you take your time and don't force things, you can do it. If you don't get it the first time just cut off the FAIL and try again. See the photo for finished examples.

  • Taper one end of feedstock using 320 grit sandpaper or a nail file; it should be slightly conical.

  • Secure the non-tapered end in a vise or locking wrench. Don't squeeze too hard otherwise the ABS will deform.

  • Place an M3 nut in a nut-driver and insert nut into tapered end of feedstock. A nut-driver works better than a wrench because the nut remains flat against the bottom. This makes keeping the nut perpendicular to the feedstock easier so you are less likely to strip or angle the threads.

  • Slowly and firmly turn the nut-driver clockwise to start threading the feedstock. Ensure the nut is perpendicular to the feedstock.

  • After completing two revolutions, turn the nut-driver counter-clockwise one revolution and blow on the feedstock to clear the feedstock threads of ABS shavings.

  • Continue this until you have threaded enough feedstock. Ten turns results in about 7 mm of threads.
    • Kustomizing
    Koming soon...

title: OpenScad Helix for custom 2D profile and many thread types

description.text:
This is a script for OpenScad to create a helix. Well, at least "half" helix. I needed a fast thread generator for printable buttress threads. So here is the result.
It is faster than intersection/difference based code and creates a single polyhedron for the complete thread. Of course, the OpenScad code could be beautified and probably be written on one line, I know,
If you find a corner case which does not work...I must say, at the moment I have other projects and I just wanted to give something back to the community. But maybe I have time later on, so if you report errors here that would be great. Before reporting please check out the TODO list in helix.scad.

You can define your custom tooth profile map of your helix if the already prepared ones in threads.scad are not ok for you. A map is a vector with x/z elements describing your profile. Check out test_rope_thread() in thread_test.scad and "rope_xz_map" in threads.scad.

If you want to "play" with the scripts, download all three scad files into the same directory and open test_threads.scad in OpenScad. There, you can adjust $fn and uncomment different test/threads (line 74).

I'm terribly sorry, but there is no help file for the parameters. But the code is commented.

Threads already implemented (not exact ISO specifications):

  • Metric threads
  • Square threads
  • ACME threads
  • Buttress threads
  • Channel threads (to "stick" something to another thing)
  • Rope threads (for rope pulleys)
  • NPT, BSP (imperial stuff, tapered gas pipes)

  • Meccano worm threads (Ha!)

  • All can have a bore in the center (pipes or other purposes)
  • All can have multiple starts

  • All support internal(nut) and external(screw) with customizable clearance according to your printer's abilities.

  • Very fast rendering, no "normalization tree" problems

Would be nice to hear if it helped in your work and what you have created with it.

Update 30.12.2016 : wanted to mention another feature:
If you want to export the polyhedron to your scad script you can uncomment some echo code in file "helix.scad" on line 2794 until 2801. Then OpenScad outputs the faces and points which you can copy/paste to your file. This way, you don't need to re-run the script every time while designing your own object where the thread is needed.

Update 23.04.2017 : Removed "debug feature" which created incorrect threads for small diameters (around 3mm).

As you can tell from one of my pictures, I lost a part of the spear/skull on the back due to lack of supports.  Use S3D or something like Meshmixer to place extra supports as needed.

description.text:
For Khaz Modan!!

It's Muradin Bronzebeard. Model taken from Heroes of the Storm (originally from https://sfmlab.com/item/503/) and converted into a 3D printable .stl. You will need LOTS of supports (see 'Print Settings - Misc Notes'). But, after removing them, I found that the model printed surprisingly well.

description.text:
Gazlowe - model taken from Heroes of the Storm (originally found here: https://sfmlab.com/item/503/). Used Blender to cut the model into more manageable pieces, but if you want to brave the full model I included it as well. I will hopefully get around to printing this soon (will be attempting the multiple piece print) and will post results when finished.

Update:
Finally got it, but it is not an easy print. I successfully printed the updated files (will upload pictures later) but be warned that the model can be very fragile, not only with the wires but the back-mounted robot makes the whole model very easy to knock over. If possible use higher perimeters/shell thickness or infill than usual (your slicer may make some parts hollow if you don't), and you will probably need modular supports (S3D or Meshmixer) in certain spots.

description.text:
It's a Remix of the RepRap syringe pump (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536373). It works well on my Prusa i3 printer. This design is 2-piece, lighter and smaller, so it can be mounted on the printer like a FDM extruder.
It takes a lead screw stepper motor, some screws and two 8mm poles to assemble it.
It uses a 5mL syringe as catridge.
When printing with this pump, everything else is the same with FDM settings, except that the "filament diameter" needs to be set as half the diameter of the syringe to start with, then calibrated by print trials. On my printer, it's 5.9mm.

Lost your Phillips? Well too bad,this one won't work!

A remix for 3ddruckqueck EQ1 Astro Tracker system. got an old stepper motor with short shaft so i'd to mount the pinion backwards. This lend me to modify the mounting plate design so i could attach the motor in the oposite position, underneath the EQ1 polar axis.

i also included oval notches for adjusting backslash of the gears (my printer still has calibration issues, and this helps to inprove gears mesh.

both gear and pinion are the same designed by 3ddruckqueck. gears requires breaking in. after some minutes readjust gear mesh and they'll run quiet. some grease helps too. also included a simple DSLR mount and a homemade knob for a 1/4" - 20 standard bolt.

Hardware required:

NEMA 17 Stepper motor
10 x M3x12mm screws
4 x M3 washer
6 x M3 nuts.
2 x M6x50mm countersunk scresw
2 x M6 locknut
1x 1/4"-20 1" HEX Screw
1 x 626-RSH, single row, deep grove ball bearing (19mm OD, 6mm ID, 6mm Widht.

Printer:

Rostock Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Supports are not required for the parts except for the motor holder.
some drilling and cleaning of the holes are required.

Instructions:

  1. use drills and countersink bits to clean all holes and notches.
  2. Insert the M3 nuts into the gears, and thread the M3 bolts.
  3. insert the ball bearing into the gears holding plate.
  4. insert the holding plate both polar axis shaft and elevation shaft.
  5. put the stepper motor in place with M3 bolts. use M3 washers to avoid print crushing. keep them loose for the moment.
  6. insert both small and big gears into the polar and motor shafts (small gear into the stepper, big gear into the polar shaft as shown in photos.
  7. tight the gears bolts. do not overtight.
  8. use a plasting bag as a gauge between both gears. hold both gears together and start tightening the motor bolts in a star pattern.
  9. with a stepper driver of your preference, and a arduino, connect your stepper and let it run for 20 minutes at a moderate speed, to the gears will wear a bit. this process is called breaking in.
  10. finally use a brush to clean both gears. add a little of grease to lubricate the transmission. it will run quietly.
  11. according to my calculations, the final transmission including the equatorial mount worm gear:

144:1 (worm gear) and 2.05:1 (printer gears) = 295.2:1. with a A4988 in a 16 microstep mode, a 200 steps motor will run at 3200 steps/revolution. if polar axis should run roughly at 23 hours 56 minutes y 4,0916 seconds (sidereal day) per revolution, this gives a 82800 s + 3360 s +4.0916 s = 86164.0916 seconds /rev. of the polar axis.
for each revolution, the steps count for the motor will be (3200 x 295.2= 944640 steps), wich gives a (86164.0916 s/944640 steps) = 0.091213681 seconds/step, or 10.9632676703 Hz.

this ~11Hz signal can be generated using an arduino. to keep costs low, a NE555 can be used. for a fast feed of the equatorial mount, a higher trigger frecuency can be used according t desired feed speed.

a switch for direction changing of the stepper. is also recommended

description.text:
This model of the Salt Lake City Mormon Temple was designed from actual photos. It has a little more detail at the top of the columns and the window count on the columns is correct, somewhat different than Kafran and Hamerhand models. It is impossible to include all the detail in a model that is 185 x 128 x 188mm High. It took the Mormons 40 years to build this temple.

Not having a picture of the rear I don't know if there were steps up to doors as in the front. So I made it the same as the front.

Printer:

Lyman V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.40mm

Infill:

8%

Notes:

I used a 0.50 nozzle with a 0.40 layer height. A smaller nozzle and layer height would give a better model. As it was, it took over 20 hours to print at 50 mm/sec filament speed. The 8% infill gave good support for the roof. However, I used a 4 layer top horizontal to get a solid roof.

Print the Angel Moroni separate. Scale it as needed. Paint it with gold spray paint and CA glue it to the front center column. The front of the model has 5 windows on the corner columns, where the rear has only 4 windows looking at the side view.

The only post printing I had to do was to paint and glue on the Angel and clean a few threads of the top of the column spires.

My model weighs 17 oz.
This model was designed with AutoCAD 11 as a solid model.

The advantage to drawing a building as a solid model other that a shell model is that you can scale it up or down without affecting the shell thickness. 2 parameters is always 2 parameters. I use infill for the support from 3 to 10% depending on the model design.

title: Shielded Stop Button for Wanhao Duplicator i3 and Maker Select

description.text:
This is a shielded stop switch for the Monoprice Maker Select, Wanhao Duplicator i3 and some other printers. I made this so I can quickly stop a print if needed, but won't risk doing it unintended. For the hinge use a piece of 1.75mm filament. I used 3M double stick tape to attach mine, seems to be sticking well. The push-pin/button just floats i the hole, without attaching it.

Update: Improved button greatly, and cover stays open once lifted.

Update 10/2/17: Added base&cover with built in hinge, so their is no assembly! (print without supports and with base laying flat).

I got the idea for this project from FingerChili's PANIC button: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1686294

Other Maker Select / i3 style printer mods I've made:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2124416
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1921236
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1943469

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

50

Notes:

I was able to print mine without support, but depending how you position it to print you may need supports for the cover.

*As this is such a small part, cooling between layers may be an issue... This can be fixed by printing the model with another item.

After printing to assemble use a piece of raw 1.75 mm filament to create the pin for the hinge. You can glue the piece in, or use a hot object (hot glue gun or your extruder on lower heat) to mushroom the ends of the pieces so that they wont fall out.

description.text:
This is a castle "rook" that I created in Eureka, and then applied a 3d texture using Eureka Texture. The faces are manipulated by a simple bit map that I created which just looks like bricks, Eureka Tec will be releasing this code in the next couple of weeks so everyone can texture objects with almost no work at all.
The object prints really well so it might be a good addition to your chess set, or castle set.

First step is to create the object in Eureka which took almost not time to create.  Then the texture was applied to the faces using the texture edit function, and then of course saved as a STL file.  Its a larger file, about 16 megs so I zipped it to decrease the download time.  I will be posint some other objects made with these tools in a day or so.

Features:

The designs include both a button or strap clip which means it can either be worn directly on the top shirt button or it can use a common bow tie strap to prevent hanging.

Furthermore there is also an adaptable and non-adaptable version. The adaptable version can interchangeably use the button or strap clip whilst the non-adaptable version requires the clip to be permanently attached with an adhesive.
I suggest using the adaptable version for more precise printers and the non-adaptable version for less precise printers as the sliding parts may not fit properly if the printer is not accurate enough.

The clip-on parts have been designed separately to prevent the use of structures for the bow tie body. Only some of the clip-ons may require structures.

print_settings.Notes:: Print the body, floorplate, and spring base without supports.  Print the follower with supports.  All .STL files are already oriented in their proper optimal printing orientation.

description.text:
Introducing a whole new portable way to store and dispense your batteries, the BatteryMag! Designed to look and function like a standard rifle magazine, this handy device holds up to 14 AA batteries. It works very well for keeping extra gadget batteries in your pack, without having them rattling around.

In addition to the 4 printed parts, you will need to cannibalize the spring out of a standard capacity (30 round) AR-15 magazine (I have tried springs out of a standard metal mag, a PMAG, and a HexMag). Alternatively, purchase one online for just a few dollars, such as this one for $3: http://www.brownells.com/magazines/rifle-magazines/magazine-parts/magazine-springs/30-round-spring-ss-sku078000109-41777-46685.aspx

Update 30Jan2017: For people with small printers, shorter bodies posted here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2073792

Printer:

XYZPrinting DaVinci 1.0A

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print the body, floorplate, and spring base without supports. Print the follower with supports. All .STL files are already oriented in their proper optimal printing orientation.

1. Print the parts.
  2. Deburr the parts. Ensure the follower fits into the body and slides smoothly. Ensure the spring base fits inside the body.
  3. Insert the magazine spring into the hollow bottom of the follower.
  4. Push the follower and spring into the body.
  5. Insert the spring base into the spring and body.
  6. Slide the floorplate onto the body, to retain the internals.
  7. Optionally, put a #6 button head wood screw into the hole on the bottom of the spring base. This will help prevent the floorplate from sliding off accidentally. To remove the floorplate with the spring installed (and magazine empty), simply push the screw and spring base in far enough to allow the floorplate to slide.

author: Seb200

print_settings.Notes:: Size

description.text:
Because I lose tubes of chapstick faster than I can buy them.

Update
People seemed to be having trouble printing this, so I've added "version 2" which should fix those issues. The entire cap is slightly larger, the keyring hole is much more solid, and the top of the cap is now flush with the keyring hole so it can be printed flat.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Plastic Dragon

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Version
"chapstick_keychain_cap_v2" will be much easier to print, and should be more durable. Use that one.

Extrusion Width
Set your extrusion width (in Cura this is called 'line width') to exactly .6mm. The walls of the cap should be one extrusion path, so use Slic3r or Cura 2.3 (older versions can't do single walls). You should also set your wall thickness to 1.2mm. If you don't set these correctly the print will come out like garbage. See the attached photo for what this should look like in Cura.

Print Orientation
You have two choices for printing this; if you print it right-side-up (the top of the cap pointed at the ceiling), it should come out looking the best. The top will have a nice finish and the keyring hole should have a nice, even curve. The downside is that it will require some bridging (unless you use supports, which I don't recommend), and it's more likely to pop off the bed.

The other option is to print it upside-down, with the top of the cap on the bed. It will stick to the bed better and you won't have to do any bridging, but the top of the cap will be a bit uglier.

Size
The cap should be very snug when you first put it on (almost hard to get on), but after a bit it will loosen up and fit well. Err on the side of too tight rather than too loose since the cap will loosen up over time and you don't want the chapstick falling out. Scale the print by a little if it doesn't fit quite right.

author: stan42

description.text:
The part to be 3d printed is "mounting bracket merged.stl".

Most optical shutters cost in the $900+ range new. These "low price" shutters are typically Teflon coated which cannot withstand high laser powers. We have seen failures of such a shutter with ~800 mW of optical power @ 950 nm. Shutters that are not Teflon coated are even more expensive.

This is a solenoid + plate solution that works for applications that do not require the shutter to close around the beam and don't need faster than 1 ms response times. This version fabricated uses an aluminum plate to block the beam. A steel plate could also be used and may tolerate even more power. The solenoid simply moves a plate in and out of the laser beam. The shutter opens with a greater than 3V digital signal into the BNC jack. The plastic screws to a 1/4-20 optical pedestal. The plate is angled down and beam can be directed into a razor blade stack.

The additional parts needed to fabricate this low cost shutter are available from Amazon.com, Ace Hardware, and RadioShack.

BOM:
3D printed Plastic Mount - 1x (mounting bracket merged.STL)
Solenoid - 1x - Amazon.com
Diode - 1x - RadioShack
FET - 1x - RadioShack/DigiKey
10 kOhm resistor - RadioShack
Prototype Board - 1x - RadioShack
Rocker Switch - 1x - RadioShack
BNC Connector - 1x -
DC 4 mm Jack - 1x - RadioShack
Aluminum Plate - 1x - Ace Hardware
M3 x Socket Head Cap Screws - 2x - Ace Hardware
6-32 x Socheck H - 2x - Ace Hardware
5V DC Wall lwart - Amazon.com

Solenoid: DC Stroke 1N Pull Push Type Open Frame Solenoid, Electromagnet, 12V, 10 mm - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00NWGT71W/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o06_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Prototype Board: RadioShack Catalog #: 2760159. I cut this in half down the middle with a band saw. 6-32 screws are used to mount to mounting bracket merged.STL. https://www.radioshack.com/collections/breadboards-ic-sockets/products/general-purpose-ic-pc-board

Diode is : 1N4003 - Purchased from RadioShack

SPST Rocker Switch: RadioShack #2750694 - https://www.radioshack.com/products/spst-red-rocker-switch

4 mm DC Jack: RadioShack #2741535 - https://www.radioshack.com/products/radioshack-size-k-coaxial-dc-power-jack-w-switch

5V DC Power Supply - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B001KU44HE/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Power FET - IRLB8743PBF - this has low on resistance to keep power dissipation by the FET low. A higher on resistance RadioShack FET might be OK too. https://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?keywords=IRLB8743pbf%20
